Are you saying that it wouldn't be a big deal if someone slandered you and your squad in front of the world before an investigation was completed? IMHO, anyone in congress should be held just as accountable as we ordinary citizens. Whether Murtha was wrong or right, there is simply no case of "slander." The reason for that is quite simple - They were indicted. For there to be slander, there would have to also be no indictment. That he gave his "opinion" that the indictment was justified, is just that, opinion. The "fact" is in the indicment. There simply was no case of slander. I don't know about the Military system of Justice, but if this was a civilian court, they could, in theory sue the state for wrongful arrest - But even then they would have to prove that the evidence was frivoulus or lacked ANY credibility. Very few win those kinds of cases. Dave
